head.title: Elegy XI. Loudon Church.1, 1 First published in Poetical Essays (1788), pp. 40-46.22 [GT's note: The burial place of the family of Loudon.] The original Loudons of Loudoun Castle, one of the oldest family seats in Scotland, were purpotedly related to the revered patriot, William Wallace; The barony passed to the Campbells in the reign of Robert the Bruce (1306-1329). During Turnbull’s life the estate was in the hands of John Campbell (1705-1782); James Mure-Campbell (1726-1786) and Flora Mure-Campbell (1780-1840) (ODNB). Located west of Loudoun Castle, Ayrshire, the late medieval Loudoun Kirk remained the parish church until the seventeenth century after which time it fell into a state of disrepair.

l.emph: There lie inter’d the more illustrious dead.

epigraph.bibl: Blair.33 Robert Blair, The Grave (1743), p. 5. An exemplar of graveyard poetry, Blair’s The Grave gained widespread popularity after it was republished in Edinburgh in 1747.

lg.l: From yonder church the ev’ning bell is toll’d,
The rising moon shines on the pointed spires,
The shepherd pens his flock within the fold,
And whistling to his lowly cot retires.
Gray ev’ning shades the landscape all around,
The plains, and silent groves, in sable drest,
From nodding tow’rs, with creeping ivy bound,
The mournful owl proclaims the hour of rest.
Mute are the feather’d songsters on each spray,
Whose joyous anthems with the ev’ning close:
Save where the turtle, with bemoaning lay,
And drousy murmurs, lulls them to repose.
How sad, how solemn is this scene of night,
Which strikes with awe the contemplative mind!
Pleasure appal’d betakes to sudden flight,
Flies like a vision, nor once looks behind.
Hark! where yon boding raven croaks aloud,
Or chatt’ring magpie, from the dusky shade,
Or wand’ring ghost, wrapt in its sable shroud,
Points out where some kind rustic shall be laid.
Yon aged Fane,44 n. a temple or church. rear’d in the days of yore,
By pious hands, for sacred ends design’d,
The dome resounds the song of praise no more,
But hangs in fragments tott’ring in the wind.
Deep in a vault which quite excludes the day,
Where bones and urns promiscuous strew the ground,
The King of terrors fits, in grim array,
Triumphing o’er his prostrate victims round.
Far from those ruin’d walls the trav’ller flies,
Soon as the ev’ning’s wrapt in dismal gloom,
Whilst through the hollow vault the zephyr sighs,
And dreadful spectres issue from the tomb.
Say, tim’rous mortal, say what makes thee run?
Why fly precipitate, and in such haste?
Why fly the drear abodes you cannot shun?
Sooner or later here we all must rest.
But thou, my Muse, whom reason’s ray directs,
Like flaming taper through the shades of night,
Let no such whims thy fancy e’er perplex,
Nor blinded superstition thee affright.
Come, wreath’d with cypress round they mournful head,
’Mongst graves, in lonely meditation roam;
Let us explore the mansions of the dead,

And read memento mori55 Latin: remember (that you have) to die. Part of the Jacobean cult of melancholia, memento mori had been an important literary theme present in such works such as Sir Thomas Browne’s Hydriotaphia (1658) as well as Jeremy Taylor’s Holy Living (1650) and Holy Dying (1651), as later in Blair’s The Grave (1743) and Thomas Gray’s Elegy Written in a Country Churchyard (1751). on each tomb.
Draw near, ye haughty, and ye proud behold,
Come and contemplate on this scene of wo:
Come view what those dumb monitors unfold,
Which tell proud mortals they must lie as low.
Promiscuous sleep, beneath the mould’ring clod,
The grave, the gay, the vicious and the just;
Of those who life’s fantastic vale have trod,
And lowly mingle with their kindred dust.
Relentless death, who can thy pow’r withstand?
Nor wealth nor honour can prolong our date,
Thou strik’st, obsequious to the High command,
Princes and peasants yield alike to fate.
Yon gloomy vaults thy ravages display,
Where lie of noble Lords a goodly train,
Who spent their lives in honour’s glorious way,
Sages in council, heroes on the plain.
For freedom still their manly bosoms burn’d,
They rear’d the shield in virtue’s godlike cause,
At tyranny, with gen’rous zeal, they spurn’d,
Which ev’ry nation to destruction draws.
Oft martial trumpets rous’d them to the war,
Their waving banners floating in the wind,
Their ensigns dreadful to the hosts afar,
Who fled and left them conquerors behind.
No more shall trumpets rouse those Chiefs to war,
No more their colours in the zephyrs fly,
No more be dreadful to the hosts afar,
No more before them slaughter’d nations lie.
High in the hall their warlike arms are hung,
No more to shine, terrific on the field,
The plumed helm, th’ elastic bow unstrung,
The bloody spear no more their arms shall wield.
This scene shall melt each gen’rous Briton’s eye,
To see the patriot rest within his urn,
Here liberty shall heave a heart-felt sigh,
And beauty here her fairest semblance mourn.
Here honour weep her bravest sons decay’d,
And valour hang apart the useless shield,
Here wealth resign at once her boasted aid,
Ev’n pride her darling ornaments must yield.
The fiercest mind, the most heroic flame,
The heart, by fame and great examples taught,
Death ev’n the most unruly will can tame,
And quite extinguish, like a transient thought.
Where are the mighty names renown’d in war,
Who to each trembling land destruction hurl’d?
Philips and Alexanders, fam’d afar,
The vainly boasted Monarchs of a world.
Where now the heroes, fam’d for mighty deeds,
Who rais’d imperial Rome to high renown?
Now from those regions liberty recedes,
And all the glory of the empire flown.
Yet do they stand renown’d in classic page,
Much to be read, and much to be admir’d,
Still shall the noble youth, in ev’ry age,
Be with their great, their bold example fir’d.
So shall the fame of Loudon’s noble line
O’er time and dark oblivion long prevail,
Their annals with irradiate lustre shine,
And youthful Warriors kindle at the tale.
